abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Reform Project
            for Montenegro were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. Lessons learned
            include: with a loan in the amount of US$5 million
            equivalent, the World Bank was able to support an important
            reform in Montenegro, sharing its international experience
            and providing on-demand advice. By project closing, the
            Government had established a strong foundation for
            continuous improvements in primary and secondary education.
            While education reforms are complex to implement, projects
            do not have to be. The Government and the Bank's team
            designed a project that was simple and supported
            strategically selected interventions, thus focusing the
            Bank's resources in these areas. Information and data
            should be used as a tool to inform stakeholders and gain
            their support for difficult decisions that are part of the
            process. Stakeholder involvement in evaluation and planning,
            through governance bodies like the multi-donor steering
            committee for this project, is vital for successful and
            sustainable projects. Bank-financed projects that perform
            well are buoyed by strong commitment from the Government and
            stakeholders, complemented by clear project objectives and
            achievable outcomes.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Serbia, Republic of Montenegro
            - Legal Amendments and Assumption of Responsibilities :
            second order restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            the Regional Vice President, Europe and Central Asia Region,
            to the Republic of Montenegro assuming responsibilities
            currently held by the Republic of Serbia, for loans, credits
            and grant related to the Republic of Montenegro
            (Montenegro), after Montenegro becomes a member of the World
            Bank, scheduled for January 18, 2007. Activities for which
            Montenegro will need to assume responsibilities include
            three IBRD loans (so-called Consolidation Loans) which were
            taken by the FRY in 2001, nine IDA credits, and four trust
            fund grants. Obligations related to the IBRD loans consist
            of principal, interest and other charges repayment. The
            proposed changes will result in Montenegro assuming formal
            responsibility for implementation, reporting, fiduciary and
            repayment and other associated obligations attached to the
            loans, credits and grants involved.

repnme.cdata!:
Serbia and Montenegro - Montenegro
            Education Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Montenegro Education Reform Project
            aims at strengthening the capacity of the education system
            to make continuous improvements, especially in the quality
            of teaching and learning in schools and in the efficient use
            of budgetary resources. The project has the following two
            components: Component 1) will extend the number of primary
            and general secondary schools included in the
            Government's reform program. About 50 schools,
            additional to those being funded by the Government, will be
            supported from the Credit. Component 2) will build capacity
            to prepare, execute and monitor a program budget; support
            the Strategy and Planning Unit to plan and implement the
            reform more effectively; support the optimization of the
            school network and staffing levels to restructure the
            budget; and assist the Government to determine and implement
            an effective plan for decentralization of education finance.
            A new Strategy and Planning Unit has been created and will
            be the focus of capacity building efforts.

Serbia and Montenegro - Montenegro Education
            Reform Project
